heading: justice department appeals copa
subheading: with only hours to spare, the justice department appealed its loss of a lawsuit that restricted online erotica in the name of protecting children. declan mccullagh reports from washington.
author: declan mccullagh
text: washington -- a law restricting online erotica does not violate free speech rights, the us government will tell a federal appeals court. the department of justice late friday appealed its loss in a lawsuit brought by opponents of the child online protection act.in february, us district judge lowell a. reed ruled that copa -- the sequel to the communications decency act -- violated free speech rights protected by the first amendment."perhaps we do the minors of this country harm if first amendment protections, which they will with age inherit fully, are chipped away in the name of their protection," reed wrote.his preliminary injunction barred the justice department from prosecuting violations of the law, which restricts web-based words or images that might be "harmful to minors."a three-judge panel chosen from the third circuit court of appeals in philadelphia, pennsylvania, is likely to rule on the case by the end of the year."the law's still going to be enjoined for the next six months. then the third circuit can affirm or reverse," said chris hansen, staff counsel for the american civil liberties union, which brought the lawsuit on 22 october.the losing side could then appeal to the full appeals court or the supreme court, the latter of which is not likely to hear the case, say legal experts.the reason: the high court in 1997 overwhelmingly struck down the portions of the cda that restricted "indecent" or "patently offensive" material online.
